page.name: Key Idea: Writing improves reading.
page.content:
Research shows that the more students learn to write about what they have read, the more reading comprehension improves. As Dr. Steve Graham notes,

“When we teach specific writing skills, their corresponding skills in reading improve. For example, teaching spelling results in improved word reading skills. Teaching sentence construction skills improves reading fluency. When we write about a text, it forces us to actively think about what we read, improving our understanding and comprehension. When we write about things that we're learning in the classroom, we come to a better conceptual understanding of the material. So writing is really a powerful tool for increasing learning in the classroom. This makes it essential for success in school.”
